div.div: The detailed calibration methods and procedure for the X-ray imaging crystal spectrometer (XICS) in the Korea Superconducting Tokamak Advanced Research device are investigated. A cross comparison from two different diagnostics including the XICS and charge exchange spectrometer is the best option, in particular, when both systems can be operated simultaneously.
I. INTRODUCTION
Section:

The tangential X-ray imaging crystal spectrometer (XICS) for the Korea Superconducting Tokamak Advanced Research (KSTAR) device shown in Fig.
1
has been actively applied to investigate core toroidal rotation and ion temperature characteristics from helium-like argon (Ar XVII) spectra since 2010. The XICS system is an important diagnostic for intrinsic toroidal rotation studies for KSTAR because XICS belongs to a passive diagnostic relying on the negligible amount of an impurity injection which does not induce an external momentum input. Although the XICS system is ideally suited for not only intrinsic rotation measurements but also all types of auxiliary heating sources, it requires a precise calibration for the toroidal rotation since the absolute wavelength calibration for the XICS diagnostic is very difficult. A detailed description of the XICS system for KSTAR including spatial resolution has been reported in previous papers.
1â5
1. S. G. Lee, J. G. Bak, M. Bitter, M. K. Moon, U. W. Nam, K. C. Jin, K. N. Kong, and K. I. Seon, Rev. Sci. Instrum.
74
, 1997 (2003).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.1535243
2. S. G. Lee, J. G. Bak, M. Bitter, K. Hill, U. W. Nam, Y. J. Kim, and M. K. Moon, Rev. Sci. Instrum.
75
, 3693 (2004).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.1785270
3. S. G. Lee, J. G. Bak, U. W. Nam, M. K. Moon, and J. K. Cheon, Rev. Sci. Instrum.
78
, 063504 (2007).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.2749441
4. S. G. Lee, J. G. Bak, U. W. Nam, M. K. Moon, Y. Shi, M. Bitter, and K. Hill, Rev. Sci. Instrum.
81
, 10E506 (2010).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.3478631
5. S. G. Lee, J. W. Yoo, Y. S. Kim, U. W. Nam, and M. K. Moon, Rev. Sci. Instrum.
87
, 11E314 (2016).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.4960491
In this paper, the detailed calibration method and procedure, and experimental results from various plasma discharges are briefly investigated.

FIG. 1.
Tangential XICS system in KSTAR.
II. CALIBRATION METHODS
Section:

As noted before, the wavelength calibration for the XICS diagnostic is very difficult so that the most simple and frequently used indirect calibration method from many devices has been applied a mode-locking.
6,7
6. M. L. Reinke, Y. A. Podpaly, M. Bitter, I. H. Hutchinson, J. E. Rice, L. Delgado-Aparicio, C. Gao, M. Greenwald, K. Hill, N. T. Howard, A. Hubbard, J. W. Hughes, N. Pablant, A. E. White, and S. M. Wolfe, Rev. Sci. Instrum.
83
, 113504 (2012).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.4758281
7. W. Yan, Z. Y. Chen, W. Jin, D. W. Huang, Y. H. Ding, J. C. Li, X. Q. Zhang, S. G. Lee, Y. J. Shi, and G. Zhung, Rev. Sci. Instrum.
85
, 11E416 (2014).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.4891058
Recently, the absolute wavelength calibration method utilizing an X-ray tube is proposed from W7-X.
8
8. J. Kring, N. Pablant, A. Langenberg, J. Rice, L. Delgado-Aparicio, D. Maurer, P. Traverso, M. Bitter, K. Hill, and M. Reinke, Rev. Sci. Instrum.
89
, 10F107 (2018).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.5038809
Figure
2
shows a typical calibration method in KSTAR based on the mode-locking induced from externally applied resonant magnetic perturbations (RMPs). When the RMP induces a stagnant mode-locking, the toroidal rotation drops to zero through electromagnetic forces in the opposite direction to the toroidal rotation. Figure
2
shows temporal behaviors of the toroidal rotation (V
Ï
) before and after calibration. Note that the measurement location for the XICS in this paper is in the plasma core with the radial and vertical positions as R = 0 m and Z = 0 m, respectively. In addition, the XICS measurements are line-averaged without inversion since the line-of-sight is limited in the core region and a typical measurement error is less than 5%.
9
9. S. G. Lee, H. H. Lee, W. H. Ko, J. W. Yoo, and KSTAR Team, Fusion Sci. Technol.
69
, 555 (2016).
https://doi.org/10.13182/fst15-174
The XICS before calibration provides a relative toroidal rotation with respect to a certain reference time since the absolute wavelength calibration could not be performed as mentioned before. Figure
2
also shows main plasma parameters and an indirect comparison with the V
Ï
direction after calibration utilizing the mode-locking since the measured core V
Ï
in KSTAR is mostly in the counter-current direction in the normal ohmic plasma discharges.
10,11
10. J. W. Yoo, S. G. Lee, S. H. Ko, J. Seol, H. H. Lee, and J. H. Kim, Phys. Plasmas
24
, 072510 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.4991397
11. S. G. Lee and J. W. Yoo, Phys. Plasmas
25
, 044502 (2018).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.5026905
This phenomenon is confirmed because the (-) sign of the V
Ï
defines a counter-current direction and the ohmic phase is lasted until 1.0 s before applying the intensive neutral beam injection. This method is ideally suited for long-pulse superconducting devices. Fortunately, the long-pulse discharges are normal operation modes in KSTAR so that we can easily apply the optimum RMP for the toroidal rotation calibration of XICS at the end of each discharge. However, the mode-locking induced from RMP frequently coincides with disruptions, as shown in Fig.
2
. This is the main disadvantage for the calibration method utilizing mode-locking.

FIG. 2.
Temporal evolution of the toroidal rotation measurement before and after calibration.

The second option for the calibration is a comparison with magnetohydrodynamics (MHD) mode rotation. The MHD shown in Fig.
3
is a sawtooth precursor with the poloidal/toroidal mode number as 1/1. If the sawtooth precursor does not move in the plasma frame, the core toroidal rotation approximately matches with the sawtooth precursor rotation unless there are strong internal kink modes and the electron diamagnetic frequency is negligible. Although this method is useful for the XICS calibration when clear sawtooth precursors appear, however, clear sawtooth precursors are not always generated in the KSTAR plasmas.

FIG. 3.
Toroidal rotation from XICS versus MHD mode rotation.

The third option for the calibration is a direct cross-comparison with the charge exchange spectroscopy (CES) which is also installed in KSTAR.
12
12. W. H. Ko, H. H. Lee, D. C. Seo, and M. Kwon, Rev. Sci. Instrum.
81
, 10D740 (2010).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.3496991
Although there is a noticeable torque from each short beam blip for CES measurement and different impurity species (argon for XICS and carbon for CES), the measured toroidal rotation and ion temperature are in good agreement in the core region, as shown in Fig.
4
. One interesting observation is that the toroidal rotation turns from the counter-current direction to the co-current direction when the first beam blip is applied at 2.0 s so that it should be carefully investigated for toroidal rotation reversal studies from the short beam blip technique. More validated experimental results from various plasmas are well summarized in Ref.
9
9. S. G. Lee, H. H. Lee, W. H. Ko, J. W. Yoo, and KSTAR Team, Fusion Sci. Technol.
69
, 555 (2016).
https://doi.org/10.13182/fst15-174
. The most advantage for this method is that the cross calibration can be performed not only in the core region but also at other location. Therefore, this simultaneous comparison will be the best option once both diagnostics are installed and operated simultaneously.

FIG. 4.
Cross comparison of the toroidal rotation and ion temperature from XICS and CES measurements.

The toroidal rotation measurements from XICS in KSTAR carefully perform the abovementioned calibration procedure in every discharge so that the XICS provides very accurate toroidal rotation data for physics studies, and all experimental data shown in this paper use the absolute toroidal rotation after calibration. In many cases, combined calibration options are applied for delicate experiments to confirm the absolute rotation value and its direction, as shown in Fig.
5
. Figure
5
shows the toroidal rotation and ion temperature characteristics with two distinctive mode-locking phases induced from the RMP and tearing mode. The first mode-locking is caused from RMP and shows a sudden toroidal rotation drop compared with the second one which is induced from the natural tearing mode.

FIG. 5.
Temporal evolutions of main plasma parameters.

Another possible candidate for the calibration is certain absorption edge lines induced from an X-ray transmission utilizing a particular thin foil. For example, a 1
Î¼
m thick Pd foil is installed between a Be-window and quartz crystal in KSTAR, as shown in Fig.
6
. The Be-window is used for the vacuum separation from the KSTAR vacuum vessel,
3
3. S. G. Lee, J. G. Bak, U. W. Nam, M. K. Moon, and J. K. Cheon, Rev. Sci. Instrum.
78
, 063504 (2007).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.2749441
and the thin Pd foil is installed directly in front of the Be-window. When intensive X-ray bremsstrahlung generated in the tokamak plasma transmits the Pd foil, Pd L-II (3.7229 Ã ) or Pd L-III (3.9071 Ã ) absorption edge lines which are located near the measured Ar spectra (3.9494â3.9944 Ã ) could be used as a wavelength-marker since the absorption edge lines are fixed and do not affect the Doppler shift due to the plasma rotation inside of the tokamak. The two laser spots in the Be-window shown in Fig.
6
indicate a careful alignment during installation of the Pd foil. Unfortunately, this option is not successful up to now since the X-ray bremsstrahlung intensity is not strong enough to apply the calibration method within a plasma discharge of tens of second. We will perform this task with the long-pulse plasma with 100 s in the future.

FIG. 6.
Inside view of the XICS crystal chamber. Before (left) and after (right) 1
Î¼
m thick Pd foil installation.
III. EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS
Section:

Figure
7
shows toroidal rotation and ion temperature characteristics with various auxiliary heating sources including ion cyclotron resonance heating (ICRH) and electron cyclotron heating (ECH). The toroidal rotation is calibrated by using the mode-locking option. The toroidal rotation and ion and electron temperature are increased clearly with the ICRH injection at 4.0 s. The toroidal rotation and ion and temperature behaviors are not shown in the earlier time before 2.6 s since the Ar gas is injected at 2.5 s. In addition, the Ar gas transport time into the plasma core region together with the ionization time generally takes about 0.1 s. More detailed experimental results from ICRH are under progress and will be reported elsewhere.

FIG. 7.
Temporal evolution of main plasma parameters and various heating sources.

Figure
8
shows the toroidal rotation and ion temperature characteristics with a cross comparison between the XICS and CES diagnostics. A short beam blip (2 Hz) and beam modulation (1â2 Hz) techniques for the CES diagnostic are simultaneously applied. The same as before, the measured toroidal rotation and ion temperature are in good agreement from the beam blip time-points. However, they show large discrepancies during the first beam modulation period where the electron density shows large variations, as shown in Fig.
8
. The main reason for the discrepancies is due to the background subtraction procedure from the CES since the electron density plays an important role for the CES background measurement. Note that the CES diagnostic needs a stable electron density during the beam modulation period for the reasonable background subtraction.
9
9. S. G. Lee, H. H. Lee, W. H. Ko, J. W. Yoo, and KSTAR Team, Fusion Sci. Technol.
69
, 555 (2016).
https://doi.org/10.13182/fst15-174

FIG. 8.
Cross comparison of the toroidal rotation and ion temperature from XICS and CES measurements.
IV. SUMMARY
Section:

The detailed calibration methods in the plasma core region for the X-ray imaging crystal spectrometer in the Korea Superconducting Tokamak Advanced Research device are investigated. These methods including a mode-locking, sawtooth precursor, cross comparison of the XICS and CES, and wavelength-marker have been described. The cross comparison from two independent diagnostics such as the XICS and CES is the best option in KSTAR since both diagnostics are operated simultaneously.

The authors would like to acknowledge the KSTAR team and especially Dr. H. H. Lee and Dr. W. H. Ko for uploading CES data to the KSTAR data server. This work was supported by the Korea Ministry of Science and ICT under the KSTAR project contracts.
